ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about social movements including resource mobilization theory, collective identity construction, media framing, and political opportunity structure. I used to believe all social movements emerged from the same factors, but this course helped me understand that movement's change tactics depending on the environment they begin in.
I learned about various theories behind social movements, and what is usually necessary to make a productive and actually IMPACTFUL movement.
Analyzing social movements from a variety of social movement theories.
I learned how to apply theoretical perspectives to social movements. I also became a better writer and learned how to organize my thoughts in a more cohesive fashion for discussions.
Throughout this course, I gained knowledge of how social movements arise. The class was taught through a series of case studies, allowing us to learn about specific movements in depth.
I developed an understanding of the various theoretical frameworks used to describe social movements and learned how to apply them to past and present movements.

Major theories and structural considerations underlying social movements, along with opportunities for real-world application. This was my first time incorporating theory into a research paper, and I actually kinda enjoyed it! Dean Barlow gives you multiple chances for experiential learning (i.e. researching a real-world, active activist or local movement)go for it! It felt very fulfilling. One insight from the course: identity and strategic movements are not mutually exclusive, and the ways they overlap can define a movements outcomes.
I learned a lot about various political theories and applied them to specific social movements; I improved my writing and presentation skills.
I learned a lot about the political theory behind social movements and then also the historical context of social movements as well.
This class was AMAZING! I feel as if I became a better reader, discusser, and writer after taking this course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class discussions were facilitated very well. Both the students and Dean Barlow were highly engaged in conversations.

Strength is that you definitely learn different words to describe aspects of a social movement. And the assessments are interesting and engaging because you get to pick your own activist, and movement, to apply what we learn to actual real life situations and write papers on them. So that was fun! You also get to learn a BIT about the histories of different movements, but thats definitely not the focus of the class so if you want the history of social movements only, don't take this course. 
I guess weakness would be that sometimes the readings were too long, and it felt occasionally like we just jumped from topic to topic without finding a thread through them all.
It was heavily discussion-based, which aided my understanding of the materials. Also, the daily discussion posts were a helpful little recap of the daily readings.
One strength was that the readings were very interesting and were not repetitive. However, one weakness was that we spent the majority of the time of discussion going over the readings.

The course was very clearly structured. I enjoyed how the lessons were organized thematically. I also enjoyed the assignments, which allowed us to focus on social movements of our own choosing. Of course, the class is probably better taught in person. However, Dean Barlow did a wonderful job keeping us engaged.

Strengths: Dean Barlow is very understanding and receptive to student feedback; she did frequently check in to ask if assignments were interesting/too much/made sense with the level of understanding we were developing throughout the course. The discussion style of the course was also really nice and the class was able to engage with all the material, even some of the denser readings, pretty well. We also had some really cool guest speakers. 
Weaknesses: I can't think of any significant weaknesses. The course is pretty heavy on the political science theory behind social movements, which can be repetitive at times, but I personally found that interesting. I will say we don't get much feedback on the essays we submit, but Professor Barlow does always say she is willing to go over your grading one-on-one if that is something you'd like.

Strengths: lots! - Diverse means of learning (reading, blogs, discussion, breakout rooms, guest speakers, research papers) that all felt fulfilling - Dean Barlow is a wonderful professor who expertly leads discussion - Mixture of (mainly) scholarly theoretical papers, but also a good number of more informal, activist-penned accounts. - Atmosphere: Our seminar truly felt like a seminar, where the discussion flowed organically, people brought up their original ideas, and the atmosphere felt just right (not too formal nor informalfriendly, inclusive, and focused). Weaknesses: hard to think of any. - perhaps historical, narrative-like accounts could have taken a larger share of the reading list, or Dean Barlow could have paired each scholarly, theory piece with an informal, news-related or activist-authored piece for application?

Strengths: interesting readings (if you like political theory and how it applies to social movements), great course structure, interesting assignments, Dean Barlow is awesome, my classmates always had very insightful things to say. It was also interesting to learn about countermovements / more conservative social movements, which I didn't expect. 
Weaknesses: Can't think of any
I think the discussion format was really great and encouraged all students to participate and talk in class which was nice, and theres not much I would change.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual seminar worked well for this class because discussion was needed to bounce ideas off of our classmates

I liked having discussion posts before each class because it helped us see what everyone was thinking about even though we were all far apart from one another. I guess I would've liked if the discussion posts were instead QUESTIONS we had, because I did that in another class and it actually made for more interesting discussion than just posing random comments about what we liked/didn't like.
I thought Dean Barlow did a great job conducting this class during COVD.

The course was set up like a seminar based around discussion over Zoom. I think it worked pretty well; our class usually engaged in pretty lively discussion and if there were any lulls Dean Barlow was always able to step in and redirect the conversation. We were put into breakout rooms periodically to discuss certain material/scenarios which I think was helpful; sometimes 10 minutes to discuss certain scenarios was a little bit too much time though.

I really appreciated Dean Barlows inclusion of blogs, breakout rooms, and guest speakersfeatures she added (or adapted) really well for the virtual class setting. Short bi-weekly blogs gave us the chance to process what we read and hear other students thoughtsand Dean Barlow incorporated students blog questions/comments into discussion, which always enhanced discussion. Breakout rooms changed the rhythm, gave us a chance to discuss (perhaps a bit more candidly) in groups of three-four. Finally, the guest speakers were fantastic: they introduced real-life narratives from various professions (one journalist, one activist) that connected with our readings and allowed for real-world applications. The two speakers were wonderful features of this course, especially given virtual teaching conditions!
Given the circumstances, the class was facilitated extremely well.
I think the discussion posts before class were really helpful and the online discussion we had live was great, so for a year of COVID, I think this class did a really good job.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! If you are interested in activism or simply want to learn more about how social movements function this is a great class to take.

Yes if you're interested in HOW social movements work. I definitely learned good stuff but wouldn't say my mind was BLOWN or anything because a fair amount of it was self explanatory so if you're kind of eh on the topic, you definitely don't need to go out of your way to take this course.
Absolutely - extremely engaging, and a great opportunity to analyze current social movements in comparison with past movements.
Yes. It is really interesting, fun, and you learn a lot.

Absolutely! This class was, by far, one of my favorite classes of my first year. Dean Barlow was an amazing professor who was clearly knowledgeable in her field. Even though we often tackled dense readings, the discussions were always enjoyable and lively.

Yes! If you have the space in your schedule and are interested in learning about how social movements form, I would definitely recommend this class. It's also very relevant to our current moment. Even though I am usually a STEM person, this class was engaging and interesting.

For sure I would. This course will add to your knowledge of how social movements actually work theres so many structural dynamics that go into a movement, and this course raises lots of important questions that any social movement participant or leader should consider. In some seminars, it can be harder to find chances to speak here Dean Barlow encourages everyone to speak to their satisfactionthis is a great course to practice speaking your mind (and even debating), which I feel many classes dont facilitate. Finally, Dean Barlow is a wonderful professor and discussion leader.
If you like political theory or social movements, you will love this course.
Yes, if you are ready to do the readings, think through the content, and share in class. Its very conversation-based, which I think can be really helpful to learning.

YES! This was an incredible first-year seminar. The topics we discussed are relevant to all the social movements that are occurring today. All of the readings were interesting. I genuinely enjoyed all of the discussions we had in class. This seminar definitely prepared me for my future classes.
